questions.text:
A 37-year-old patient came to see you with flexion at the proximal interphalangeal joint and hyperextension of the 4th and 5th metacarpophalangeal joints.
The likely nerve injured is:
questions.solution:
An ulnar nerve injury that causes partial or complete denervation of the ulnar (medial) two lumbricals of the hand may be followed by an ulnar claw.
Due to the fact that the ulnar nerve supplies the third and fourth lumbrical, which flex the MCP joints, its denervation enables these joints to extend as a result of the long finger extensors' now-unopposed action (namely the extensor digitorum and the extensor digiti minimi). By inserting into the extensor hood,the lumbrical and interossei also extend the IP (interphalangeal) joints of the fingers; their paralysis leads to weakened extension. Combined with hyperextension at the MCP provides the hand its claw-like shape.






Reference-: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition Page no 984,984.e1

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about the basal electrical rhythm of the intestines?
questions.solution:
Instead of the amplitude, the stimulus frequency determines the tone of the contraction.

The interstitial cells of Cajal present in the Aurbachs plexus produces slow waves, also known as Basal Electric Rhythm(BER) which is cyclical variations in Resting Membrane Potential varying between -40 to -60 mv. When a stimulus comes in the form of food, hormones etc BER + stimulus forms the Spike potential causing Ca ions to bind to calmodulin and causing muscle contraction + movement. 

Value of BER varies with site in the GIT.
Stomach 4/min
Duodenum 12/min
Ileum 9/min
Caecum  2/min
Colon and Rectum 4-6/min

questions.text: Determine the ejection fraction using the volume pressure curve that is given.
questions.solution:
From the provided pressure-volume loop,
AB: Isovolumetric contraction from the provided pressure-volume loop
BC: Systolic contraction of the ventricles
CD:Isovolumetric relaxation
Hence,
130 mL is the End-Diastolic Volume (EDV) (Point a).
50 mL is the End Systolic Volume (ESV) (Point d)
Flow Volume (SV) 80 mL = EDV-ESV
Ejection Fraction = SV/EDV = 80/130 = 0.6, or 60% EF

questions.text: What will be the tetanizing frequency for the muscle if the latent duration of a muscle twitch is 10 ms, the contraction time is 40 ms, and the relaxation time is 50 ms?
questions.solution:
Tetany is defined as continuous muscle fibre contraction with no latent period or relaxation time.
Tetanizing solely depends on the length of the twitch, or the duration of the contraction.
Twitch duration=40ms=0.04sec
Tetanizing Frequency= 1/ Contraction period 
Therefore, tetanizing frequency=1/0.04=25Hz

questions.text: 10 mEq/mmol of potassium is present extracellularly while 100 mEq/mmol is present intracellularly. According to the Nernst equation, what will be the equilibrium potential for potassium?
questions.solution:
The membrane potential at which ion influx and outflow are in equilibrium is known as the equilibrium potential.
The potential of an ion with charge z across a membrane can be calculated using the Nernst equation
The concentration of the ion both within and outside the cell is used to calculate this potential:


 
  • E= The membrane potential
  • [C]o - ion outside the cell = The extracellular concentration of that ion= 10 
  • [C]i - ion inside the cell= The intracellular concentration of that ion= 100
  • Z= Va (Valence of K+)
The membrane potential must match the Nernst potential when the membrane is at thermodynamic equilibrium (i.e., there is no net ion flux).

Inputting the values 

Membrane potential = 61/ 1(valence) X log10 (10/100)
= 61 X [1-2]. (since log a/b = log a - log b, log 10 is 1, log 100 is 2)
= 61x -1 = -61mV ~ -60mV

Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26th Page no 9

questions.text: What does the selenocysteine codon look like?

questions.text: The following findings are revealed by a liver biopsy. What is true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Nutmeg liver with dark areas of perivenular dead hepatocytes and gray areas of periportal viable hepatocytes
 
  • This iconic image of Nutmeg liver shows the liver with chronic passive venous congestion. Necrotic hepatocytes make up the dark, crowded spots, whereas viable hepatocytes are present in the paler, brownish-looking areas around them.
  • In chronic passive hepatic congestion, the centrilobular regions are grossly red-brown and slightly depressed (because of cell death) and are accentuated against the surrounding zones of uncongested tan liver (nutmeg liver).
  • Microscopically, there is centrilobular congestion and hemorrhage, hemosiderin-laden macrophages, and variable degrees of hepatocyte dropout and necrosis
To remember this, think the blood supply comes via portal vein and Hepatic artery from the portal triad towards the center of the lobule, so when there is stasis the first to be affected is the centrilobular area than the periportal area which is close to the vascularity. It is therefore - Periportal fibrosis and Centrilobular necrosis seen in CVC liver
                                        

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 533.

choices.text: H. pylori infection, Silver stain, Gram-negative coccobacilli

questions.text:
A 30-year-old male patient complains of heartburn. An upper GI endoscopy was done and a biopsy from a suspicious lesion showed the following picture.
What is the significance of this? What particular stains are you going to use for confirmation, and what are you looking for?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Barrett’s esophagus, mucin stain, dysplasia
 
  • The histological picture of the esophagus shows intestinal-type epithelium with goblet cells, characteristic of Barrett's esophagus.
  • Mucin stain helps to better define the extent of dysplasia and rule out malignant transformation.
  • Diagnosis of Barrett esophagus requires endoscopic evidence of metaplastic columnar mucosa above the gastroesophageal junction. Microscopically, intestinal-type metaplasia is seen as replacement of the squamous esophageal epithelium with goblet cells.
  • Goblet cells are diagnostic of Barrett esophagus and have distinct mucous vacuoles that stain pale blue and impart the shape of a wine goblet to the remaining cytoplasm.
  • Non-goblet columnar cells, such as gastric-type foveolar cells, may also be present, but there is not universal agreement as to whether they are sufficient for the diagnosis.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 761.

questions.text: Cell growth can be halted at certain stages in the cell cycle. Which stage of the cell cycle displays the main major point in cell growth regulation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) End of G1

The first and most significant cell-cycle checkpoint is G1-S, or towards the end of the G1 phase, which is where the Rb gene and p53 both regulate the cell cycle.

*[Extra Edge]: RB Gene
 
  • If the phosphorylation of the RB gene is paused, it will result in the cell cycle stopping at the G1 phase.
  • The RB gene (retinoblastoma gene) is a tumor suppressor gene that regulates the cell cycle progression. When RB is phosphorylated, it becomes inactive and allows the cell cycle to proceed from G1 phase to S phase.
  • However, if RB phosphorylation is paused or inhibited, it prevents the release of transcription factors required for DNA replication, leading to cell cycle arrest at the G1 phase. 
                                                                     

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 295.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most significant but nonspecific regulator of iron metabolism?
questions.solution:
Hepcidin is a key regulator of iron homeostasis that controls iron absorption in the intestine and iron release from macrophages and hepatocytes. It acts by binding to and causing the degradation of ferroportin, the cellular iron exporter, thereby reducing iron absorption from the gut and iron release from stores. Hepcidin levels increase in response to elevated iron levels, inflammation, and other factors, helping to prevent iron overload.

 

Reference-: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease Edition 10 th Page no 646

choices.text: Gives an immediate definitive diagnosis of tumor
Used for detecting positive margins after resection
Sentinel lymph node biopsy in breast carcinoma is an example

questions.text: Everything about intraoperative histopathological analysis is correct except the following statement:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Gives an immediate definitive diagnosis of tumor
 
  • Intraoperative frozen section may be helpful to determine the extent of surgery but cannot gives an immediate definitive diagnosis of tumor because the quality is inferior to that of routine material, resulting in a potential reduction in diagnostic accuracy and precision.
  • Pathologic confirmation of cancer is mandatory before initiating treatment, but this can be done by a biopsy with frozen section during the same anesthetic before a planned complete resection.
  • Sentinel lymph node biopsy in breast carcinoma is an example where Frozen can be done to determine the extent of surgery

Fig: Frozen section (FS) of a sentinel lymph node demonstrated the presence of a micrometastasis

* [Extra Edge]: Frozen section
 
  • Frozen section diagnosis is useful when a very rapid answer is necessary.
  • The surgeon supplies a small representative fresh tissue sample of the area of interest.
  • A BMS freezes the tissue quickly in the pathology laboratory and can produce sections for microscopic examination within several minutes. There are a few disadvantages in comparison with routine processing: fresh tissue carries a higher risk of infection; the quality is inferior to that of routine material, resulting in a potential reduction in diagnostic accuracy and precision; small but representative samples are necessary; certain types of tissue (e.g. fat) are difficult to process; and the process is time-consuming and disruptive.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 182.

questions.text:
Some gram-negative bacteria develop an enzyme that prevents beta lactam antibiotics from acting in the periplasm.
Which arrow in the Penicillin G structural diagram represents the site of action of this enzyme?
questions.solution:

  • Beta-lactam is an amide bond found in the structure of Penicillin G, as represented by 'B' above.
  • Beta-lactamases are the enzymes produced by some bacteria which provide resistance to beta-lactam antibiotics like penicillins, cephamycins, and carbapenems by breaking the antibiotics' structure.

questions.text: To explore the effects of medicines on intestinal contractility, a guinea pig is dissected and a piece of its intestine is fixed in the modified Dales chamber. Following the addition of material X to the soup, the graph appears as shown. Which of these compounds is most similar to Substance X
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Epinephrine

After receiving drug X, contractility is shown to have decreased on this graph. When acetylcholine acts on M3 receptors, intestinal muscles become more contractile, but epinephrine inhibits contraction. Therefore, it is likely that substance X is epinephrine, a sympathomimetic medication.

In isolated preparations of gut, activation of both α and β receptors produces relaxation. In intact animals and man peristalsis is reduced and sphincters are constricted, but the effects are brief.

Epinephrine interaction with adrenoceptors G-protein mediated stimulation of cell membrane bound adenylyl cyclase increased intracellular cyclic 3',5'AMP cardiac stimulation, hepatic glycogenolysis, hyperglycemia and gut relaxation etc.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 144.

questions.text: Which class of drugs can only be administered/bought after a prescription from qualified medical practitioners?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Schedule H

Schedule H is a class of prescription drugs in India appearing as an appendix to the Drugs and Cosmetics Rules, 1945. These medications require a prescription from a licensed physician to be acquired over the counter.

Other Important Schedules: -

Schedule X- narcotics and psychotropic drugs 
Schedule G- Includes hormonal medications


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 7.

questions.text: Which of the following medications is a calcineurin inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Cyclosporine
 
  • The immune system's T cells are activated by the calcium and calmodulin-dependent serine/threonine protein phosphatase known as calcineurin.
  • It dephosphorylates the transcription factor nuclear factor of activated T cell, cytoplasmic (NFATc), activating it. The nucleus is where the activated NFATc is translocated after which it increases the expression of IL-2, which in turn derives the development and differentiation of T cells.
  • A class of medications known as calcineurin inhibitors, which includes cyclosporine, pimecrolimus, and tacrolimus, target calcineurin.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 937, 939.

questions.text: Which substance falls under the category of an antifibrinolytic?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Epsilon aminocaproic acid
 
  • The plasmin-plasminogen system is artificially inhibited by epsilon-aminocaproic acid (EACA). It is the sole effective antifibrinolytic substance that is marketed.
  • It is an analog and derivative of the amino acid lysine, making it a potent inhibitor of enzymes that bind to that specific residue.
  • Proteolytic enzymes like plasmin, the enzyme in charge of fibrinolysis, are examples of such enzymes. This makes EACA useful in the treatment of several bleeding problems.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 676.

questions.text: What effect is dopamine capable of producing at low infusion rates of 3-5 mcg/kg/min?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Increased cardiac contractility
 
  • Dopamine action: D1 receptors at 2 mcg (renal vasodilation);
  • Beta receptors (2–10 mcg) (increased cardiac contractility);
  • alpha receptors (10–100 mcg) (vasoconstriction).
Higher doses of dopamine (5-10 mcg/kg/min) can increase cardiac contractility by stimulating beta-1 adrenergic receptors,

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 146.

questions.text: Aspirin inhibits platelet aggregation through its effect on:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Thromboxane A2
 
  • Low-dose aspirin use irreversibly blocks the formation of thromboxane A2 in platelets, producing an inhibitory effect on platelet aggregation. (This happens via inhibition of cyclooxygenase and thromboxane synthase inhibition).
  • This antiplatelet property makes aspirin useful for reducing the incidence of heart attacks.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 211.

questions.text: What is the purpose of the Phase 1 clinical trial?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Drug safety

Phase I: Human pharmacology and safety

The emphasis is on safety, tolerability, and to detect any potentially dangerous effects on vital functions, such as precipitous fall/rise in blood pressure or heart rate, arrhythmias, bronchospasm, seizures, kidney/liver damage, etc.
Unpleasant side effects are noted and an attempt is made to observe the pharmacodynamic effects in man. The human pharmacokinetic parameters of the drug are measured for the first time.

Although Dosing, Pharmacodynamics is also being carried out in Phase 1 but most appropriate answer would be Drugs safety.


* Exam points about Drug development:




Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 90.

questions.text: Which of the following medications, when acting on dilator pupillae, has an action similar to pilocarpine on sphincter papillae?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1): Timolol

The Iris sphincter, which is made up of circularly arranged muscle fibers, and the iris dilator, which is made up of radially arranged muscle fibers, are the two types of muscles that regulate the size of the iris. The parasympathetic nervous system innervates the sphincter, while the sympathetic nervous system innervates the dilator.

The radial muscle contracts as a result of sympathetic stimulation of the adrenergic receptors, and the pupil then enlarges. Contrarily, parasympathetic activation results in circular muscle contraction and thus the constriction of the pupil.

* Miotics: (Fig C)
  • Cholinergic: Pilocarpine, Physostigmine, Methacholine
  • Sympatholytic: Timolol, Propranolol

* Mydriatics (with or without cycloplegia): (Fig B)
  • Sympathomimetics: Phenylephrine, adrenaline, cocaine
  • Anticholinergics: Tropicamide, cyclopentolate, atropine, hyoscyamine, and scopolamine.




Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 126.

questions.text: Which of the following medications has no effect on DNA synthesis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Linezolid
 
  • Linezolid inhibits protein synthesis by attaching to the 50S subunit and preventing the initiation complex formation.
  • Nitrofurantoin acts by damaging bacterial DNA.
  • Metronidazole acts by forming toxic free radicals that damage DNA.
  • Rifampin acts by inhibiting the DNA-dependent RNA polymerase.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 807.

questions.text: What exactly does a drug's low volume of distribution imply?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Does not accumulates in tissues

A low volume of distribution implies that the drug remains confined to the plasma compartment without getting distributed in the body tissues.  

* Audio Explanation:


Vd = Dose of drug(mg)/Concentration of drug in blood(mg/L)


* Factors governing volume of distribution:
 
  • Lipid:Water partition coefficient of the drug
  • pKa value of the drug
  • Degree of plasma protein binding
  • Affinity for different tissues
  • Fat: Lean body mass ratio
  • Disease like CHF, Uremia, cirrhosis

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 23.

questions.text: Which medication from the list below is not used to treat bird flu?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Ribavirin 

  • There are specific antiviral medications for influenza, including amantadine and rimantadine for influenza A as well as the neuraminidase inhibitors zanamivir, oseltamivir, and peramivir for both influenza A and influenza B.
  • A nucleoside analogue ribavirin has action in vitro against influenza A and B viruses.
  • When given as an aerosol, it has been reported to be varyingly effective against influenza but ineffective when given orally.
  • Its effectiveness in treating influenza A or B has not been shown.
  • Hepatitis C, viral hemorrhagic fevers, and RSV are the main conditions that ribavirin is used to treat.
* Audio Explanation:


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 856.

choices.text: To be given empty stomach with a glass of water

questions.text: What directions should be given to a patient while administering bisphosphonates?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) To be given empty stomach with a glass of water
 
  • Oral bisphosphonates have the potential to cause stomach discomfort, inflammation, and esophageal erosions.
  • This can be avoided by taking the drug on an empty stomach and being seated upright for 30 to 60 minutes afterward.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 370.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs absorbs most readily after a fatty meal?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Griseofulvin
 
  • Griseofulvin inhibits microtubule formation and thereby disrupts the assembly of the mitotic spindle.
  • Improved absorption when the drug is taken with a fatty meal. 
* [Extra Edge]: Griseofulvin
  1. Griseofulvin interferes with mitosis—multi­ nucleated and stunted fungal hyphae are produced under its action. Metaphase arrest does not occur, but daughter nuclei fail to move apart or move only a short distance. It binds to polymerized microtubules and interferes with their function.
  2. The absorption of griseofulvin from g.i.t. is incomplete because of very low water solubility. Absorption is improved by taking it with fats and by microfining the drug particles. Griseofulvin is keratophilic; gets deposited in keratin forming cells of skin, hair and nails.
  3. Griseofulvin is used orally only for dermatophytosis. On getting deposited in the skin through circulation, it prevents fungal invasion of keratin. Because it is fungistatic and not cidal, the newly formed keratin is not invaded by the fungus, but the fungus persists in already infected keratin, till it is shed off.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 77.

questions.text: Which of these cancers cannot be treated with steroids?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Kaposi sarcoma
 
  • Steroids are often included in the treatment of certain cancers as combination chemotherapy.
  • These include both acute and chronic lymphocytic leukemias, Hodgkin as well as non-Hodgkin lymphoma, multiple myeloma, breast cancer and medulloblastoma.
  • In HIV-infected individuals, the use of glucocorticoids is a risk factor for KS-IRIS and Kaposi's sarcoma-associated mortality. In addition, KS-IRIS is a risk factor for mortality.
  • Therefore, glucocorticoid administration in this population requires careful consideration based on individualized risk–benefit analysis.
Online Reference: 
Fernández-Sánchez M, Iglesias MC, Ablanedo-Terrazas Y, Ormsby CE, Alvarado-de la Barrera C, Reyes-Terán G. Steroids are a risk factor for Kaposi's sarcoma-immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome and mortality in HIV infection. AIDS. 2016 Mar 27;30(6):909-14. doi: 10.1097/QAD.0000000000000993. PMID: 26636923; PMCID: PMC4794188.

questions.text: Which anticonvulsant causes the vision field to contract?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Vigabatrin

  • The retinal nerve fiber layer suffers from permanent widespread atrophy brought on by vigabatrin.
  • The outside region of the retina is mainly affected by this (as opposed to the macular or central region), which causes contraction of visual field.
  • Taurine depletion may be the cause of vigabatrin's retinal toxicity.

questions.solution:
The image shows filamentous Gram-stained Nocardia.
They are also acid-fast and can be stained by the Modified Ziehl­ Neelsen technique. Nocardia asteroides is the most frequently found species infecting humans, and most cases occur as an opportunistic infection in immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: The genital ulcer was used to prepare a smear. Pick out the responsible organism.
questions.solution:
The above image is of trichomonas vaginalis.
Women who are infected typically have a translucent "halo" surrounding their superficial cell nucleus on a cervical smear.
It is unreliably detected by studying a genital discharge or with a cervical smear because of their low sensitivity.
A wet mount was previously used to diagnose T. vaginalis, and "corkscrew" motility was noted.

Currently, overnight cultures, which have a sensitivity range of 75–95 percent, are the most popular method of diagnosis. Even more sensitive techniques exist, but they are not commonly used.
Two examples are transcription-mediated amplification and fast antigen testing. PCR can be used to detect T. vaginalis if GENBANK/L23861-specific primers are used.
 

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 37.

questions.text: An ulcer in the vaginal area was seen in a 24-year-old female patient. The following image was obtained from a cervical smear that had been Giemsa stained. Determine the responsible agent
questions.solution:
Coccobacilli seen in the above giemsa-stained specimen suggest a diagnosis of Granuloma Inguinale. Donovan bodies are seen intracellularly in mononuclear cells.
Granuloma lnguinale:
Donovanosis, also known as granuloma inguinale, is a long-lasting inflammatory condition brought on by Calymmatobacterium granulomatis, a tiny, encapsulated coccobacillus closely linked to the Klebsiella genus. The organism is sexually transmitted. Presents with the painless genital ulcer.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 404.

Cryptococcus neoformans:
Causes Cryptococcal cryptococcosis.
Encapsulated.
Not dimorphic.
Found in soil, pigeon droppings
Acquired through inhalation with hematogenous dissemination to meninges.
Culture on sabouraud agar.
Stains with India Ink and mucicarmine.
Latex agglutination test detects polysaccharide capsular
antigen and is more specific.
'Soap bubble' lesions in the brain.
C. neoformans grows as yeast (unicellular) and replicates by budding.

questions.text: A patient complains of progressive dyspnea. Chest X-ray indicated a cavitary lesion in lower lobe of right lung. The excision of the cavity had the following histological appearance. What is the most likely source of this condition, and how many layers can be seen in the parasite's wall?
questions.solution:
The following histopathological image represents a typical Hydatid cyst, which is caused  by the dog tapeworm Echinococcus.The larvae settle inside the capillaries of the various organs and first trigger an inflammatory response made up primarily of mononuclear leukocytes and eosinophils. Many of these larvae are killed, but some encyst.
An inner, nucleated, germinative layer and an outer, opaque, non-nucleated layer surround an opalescent fluid.
The characteristic outer non-nucleated layer features numerous thin laminations that give the impression that it is formed of multiple layers of gelatin.

questions.text: This  blood smear indicates the presence of which species?
questions.solution:
The Plasmodium species shown in the image is Plasmodium falciparum, identifiable by the characteristic crescent/Banana-shaped gametocytes.

Other Plasmodium species, such as Plasmodium vivax, Plasmodium ovale, or Plasmodium malariae, do not typically produce gametocytes with this distinct crescent shape. Instead, their gametocytes are usually round or oval.

questions.text: A patient arrives at your clinic complaining of three days of loose, watery stools. After more investigation, you discover that these episodes began three days after he consumed shellfish at a nearby restaurant and that other people who ate at that restaurant experienced identical symptoms. What is the most prevalent cause of viral diarrhea in adults?
questions.solution:
The most typical cause of viral gastroenteritis in people is norwalk virus. 
The virus can spread from person to person, by direct contact with feces-contaminated food or drink, and through aerosolization of the virus and subsequent surface contamination.
Infection with norwalk virus is characterized by watery diarrhea, abdominal pain, and, occasionally, loss of taste. There may be a general weakness, muscle aches, headaches, and mild fever.
The foods that cause norwalk virus outbreaks the most frequently are shellfish and salad elements.
Consuming shellfish that has not been heated adequately increases the chance of contracting norwalk virus.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 565.

questions.text: Which disease's immunopathogenesis is associated with antibody-dependent enhancement?
questions.solution:
• Antibody-dependent enhancement (ADE) also known as the Halsted phenomenon happens when non-neutralizing antiviral antibodies make it easier for viruses to enter host cells, increasing the cells' capacity to spread infection.
  • Some cells lack the typical receptors that viruses employ to attach to their surfaces. The antiviral proteins, or antibodies, attach to antibody Fe receptors found on the plasma membrane of certain of these cells. The antigen-binding site on the antibody's opposite end is where the viruses attach.
  • The scenario of dengue virus infection is the most well-known instance of ADE (DENV). This virus can infect human macrophages through this route, turning a typically moderate viral infection into a potentially fatal condition.
  • The phenomenon of ADE may be observed when a person who has previously been infected with one serotype of DENV becomes infected many months or years later with a different serotype.
  • This explains the finding that while primary infections (initial infections) primarily result in moderate disease (DF) in children, secondary infections (re-infections at a later time) are more frequently linked to severe disease (DHF and/or DSS) in both children and adults.
Audio explanation for the above.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 270.

questions.text: Which of the following causes a phage-mediated change in C. diphtheria?
questions.solution:
Phage-mediated change in C. diphtheria is due to Transduction. 
In transduction, donor DNA is carried by a phage coat and is transferred into the recipient by the mechanism used for phage infection. 

Conjugation: Transfer of genetic material between bacterial cells by direct cell-to-cell contact or by a
the bridge-like connection between two cells.

Transformation: Genetic alteration of a cell resulting from the direct uptake and incorporation of exogenous genetic material from its surroundings and taken up through the cell membrane.

Transduction: DNA is transferred from one bacterium to another by a virus or the process whereby foreign DNA is introduced into another cell via a viral vector.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 60.

questions.text: The odour of shoe polish can be seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Nitrobenzene

Nitrobenzene is an oily yellow-to-yellow-brown liquid that smells like bitter almonds or shoe polish. 
The most frequent exposure occurs in jobs where nitrobenzene is used to make dyes, medications, pesticides, or some kinds of rubber. Exposure can happen through your breath or through physical contact.

Other options: -
1. Mercaptans smell- garlic or smelly feet
2. Lacquer odour- banana smell
3. Paraldehyde odour- pungent like acetic acid

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd edition, Page No 501.

questions.text: Which acid does not cause coagulation necrosis when it comes into contact with it?
questions.solution:
HF differs from other corrosive poisons in that it chelates calcium, which is required for coagulation, and does not result in coagulation necrosis. While other corrosive acids cause desiccation or denaturation of superficial tissue proteins, often resulting in the formation of an eschar or coagulum. HF causes liquefaction necrosis. Among the options the best option is HF

questions.text: After a quarrel, a husband sprays sulfuric acid on his wife, who then visits the emergency room for supportive care. All of the following are true regarding chemical burns, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3. Absence of singeing of hairs
 
  • Sulfuric acid is a strong acid that can cause significant thermal injury in addition to chemical burns.
  • When sulfuric acid comes into contact with skin, it can generate heat due to its exothermic reaction, potentially causing singeing of hairs.
  • Therefore, singeing of hairs may indeed be present in such burns.
  • The hydroxyl ion produces a saponification of fat, soluble alkaline proteinases, cellular dehydration and an exothermic reaction. The ion passes from molecule to molecule, denaturing each in burn, and burrows deeply, producing soft gelatillous, friable eschars (liquefaction necrosis).

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 499.

questions.text: An autopsy conducted by a doctor revealed that a married woman, age 26, poisoned herself with aluminium phosphide, which was the cause of death. He voluntarily conceals this information in a court of law when she was summoned. Which part of the law makes this punishable?
questions.solution:
Section 193 in The Indian Penal Code
193-Punishment for false evidence.
Whoever intentionally gives false evidence in any stage of a judicial proceeding, or fabricates false evidence for the purpose of being used in any stage of a judicial proceeding, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which. may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine, and whoever intentionally gives or fabricates false evidence in any other case, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 55.

questions.text: Which of the following options is related to Ewing's postulates?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Complication resulting from trauma

Ewing's postulates concerns with growth at site following :

A. The tumor must arise exactly at the site injured
B. Definite and substantial trauma must be proved
C. The tumor must be confirmed pathologically
D. The tissue at the site must have been healthy before the trauma;
E. A reasonable interval-neither too long or too short-must elapse between the time of the trauma and the appearance of the tumor
F. Though not one of the Ewing's original postulates, there should be some good scientific reason for ascribing the tumor formation to the injury and this is rarely possible.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 293.

questions.text: Boiled lobster syndrome is evident in poisoning of:
questions.solution:
* Boric acid poisoning:
-Rarely fatal in adults because of the large amount needed for serious toxicity. 
-Non-specific gastrointestinal symptoms make up the first stage of poisoning.
-The 'boiled lobster' rash, an intense generalized erythroderma, manifests shortly thereafter, with extensive desquamation within 1-2 days.
-Serious effects of borate poisoning include cardiovascular collapse, seizures, and renal failure.
-The only potential therapy is dialysis or exchange transfusion which has been anecdotally effective.
-The main symptoms of boric add poisoning are blue­ green vomit, diarrhea, and a bright red rash on the skin.

Reference: Schillinger BM, Berstein M, Goldberg LA, Shalita AR. Boric acid poisoning. J Am Acad Dermatol. 1982 Nov;7(5):667-73. doi: 10.1016/s0190-9622(82)70149-5. PMID: 6216273.

Atropine premedication should be used before administering Neostigmine

questions.text: Which of the following statements concerning snake bites is false?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is Option 4 Neostigmine has a role in krait bite

Neostigmine and atropine are only effective in cobra bites (neurotoxic poisons).

If there are signs of neuro paralysis, give 1.5 mg neostigmine for adults i.m. with 0.6 mg atropine i.v. to counteract the muscarinic effects of neostigmine. It is repeated twice at ten minutes interval. In cases of presynaptic envenoming such as kraits or Russell's viper a positive response does not occur. Before every injection, half mg. atropine should be given to block muscarinic side effects.

* Families of poisonous snakes:
  • Elapidae (king cobra, common cobra, common krait): Neurotoxic 
  • Viperidae (Russel viper, Saw Scaled viper, Humped pit viper): Hemotoxic 
  • Hydrophinae (Sea snakes): Myotoxic 
* Management of snakebite is as follows:
  • First aid: Carry No RIGHT
    • Carry- do not allow victim to walk
    • No- No tourniquet, No sucking, No electrotherapy, No incison, No pressure immobilisation
    • R- Reassurance (Most bites are by non-venomous snakes)
    • I- Immobilise the patient
    • GH- Get to Hospital immediately
    • T- tell doctor about any specific symptom noticed during shifting to hospital
* Pressure immobilization is for elapid bite when patient id >1 hour from medical care
  • ASV given if signs of poisoning seen (effective against 4 snakes – Common cobra, krait, saw scaled viper, Russel viper)
  • IV Neostigmine and Atropine given for neuroparalysis.
  • Wound debridement
  • Dialysis
  • FFP

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 565.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is cured with the following treatment?
questions.solution:
For both multibacillary and paucibacillary leprosy, WHO has created blister pack medicine kits.
 
  • The single lesion paucibacillary leprosy blister pack medicine kit comes with everything needed to administer the three drugs just once. 
  • Any patient who has a positive skin smear must get the MDT multibacillary leprosy treatment regimen.
  • A patient with multibacillary leprosy should never get the paucibacillary leprosy treatment regimen.
  • As a result, if a patient's diagnosis is unclear, that patient should be treated with the MDT regimen for multibacillary leprosy.

questions.text: Which of the following viruses' life cycles is most similar to the one described below?
questions.solution:
The figure quite clearly depicts that the life cycle shown is that of the Japanese Encephalitis Virus.
  • In contrast to the other choices described above, humans are dead ends and incidental hosts in the life cycle of these viruses.
  • Humans, cattle and horses are dead-end hosts as the disease manifests as fatal encephalitis.
  • Swine play a crucial part in the epidemiology of the disease by acting as an amplifying host.
  • Infection in swine is usually asymptomatic.
  • The most significant vector is the Culex tritaeniorhynchus, which prefers to feed on cattle as compared to humans.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 332.

questions.text: The box plot below depicts the distribution of three sets of data around the mean. What is the correct order of inference from this box plot?
questions.solution:
The direction of the tail, or the direction of the values with the least frequency, designates whether a set of data is positively or negatively skewed.
  • The data set is divided into quartiles using a boxplot.
  • A "box" (hence the name) extending from the first quartile (Ql) to the third quartile (Q3) makes up the body of the boxplot.
  • A line is drawn inside the box at Q2, at the midpoint, designating the median of the data set.
  • The box has two whisker-like lines that protrude from the front and back. The back whisker extends from Q3 to the largest non-outlier, and the front whisker extends from Q1 to the smallest non-outlier in the data set.
  • If there are any outliers in the data set, they are shown as independent points.
On rotating clockwise, 
1st pic= normal distribution
2nd pic= negatively skewed as tailing or elongation is on left side.
3rd pic = positively skewed as tailing or elongation is on right side.

Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 7.

questions.text:
The scatter plot below depicts the association between weight and height in four separate samples.
What is the net correlation coefficient if all four samples have the same coefficient of correlation of 0.6?
questions.solution:
The slope of the graph provides the coefficient of correlation.
The net correlation coefficient will remain at 0.6 because the slopes of all four populations are the same, at 0.6.
  • Correlation coefficient is a linear link between two variables which can be measured by the value r, and is also known as the linear correlation coefficient or the Pearson product moment correlation coefficient.
  • If there is a “perfect” linear relationship between the two variables so that it is possible to know the exact value of one variable from knowledge of the other variable, the correlation coefficient r will be exactly ±1.00.
  • If there is absolutely no relationship between the two variables, so that it is impossible to know anything about one variable on the basis of knowledge of the other variable, then the coefficient will be zero.
  • Coefficients beyond ±0.5 are typically regarded as strong, whereas coefficients between 0 and ±0.5 are usually regarded as weak. 
Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 36.

questions.text: What is the following data description called?
questions.solution:
• In a specific table called a "Stem and Leaf Plot," each data value is divided into a "stem" (the initial digit or digits) and a "leaf" (usually the last digit).
  • To help visualize the shape of a distribution, a stem-and-leaf display is a tool for presenting quantitative data in a graphical style, comparable to a histogram.
  • Two columns are divided by a vertical line in a straightforward stem-and-leaf layout. The stems are in the left column, and the leaves are in the right column.
In order to give the reader a fast overview of distribution, stem-and-leaf displays are helpful for illustrating the relative density and shape of the data. The majority of the original numerical data is retained, frequently in complete fidelity. They are helpful for identifying outliers and emphasizing data as well.


Online reference: https://statisticsbyjim.com/graphs/stem-and-leaf-plot/

questions.text:
A latex agglutination test for meningitis detection has been authorised. Based on the following data, compute the test's sensitivity and specificity:
Test Positive Test Negative
Diseased 27 3
Non-diseased 5 95
questions.solution:
• Sensitivity, which is also known as the true positive rate (e.g. the percentage of sick people. who are correctly identified as having the condition).
 
  • Specificity measures the percentage of true negatives that are accurately classified as such (also known as the true negative rate) (e.g. the percentage of healthy people who are correctly identified as not having the condition).

Here,
27 =True Positives
95 =True Negatives
5 =False Positives
3 =False Negatives

Thus,
Sensitivity = 27/30= 90%
Specificity = 95/100 = 95%.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 155.

Which of these is the most effective tool for demonstrating the complexities?
questions.solution:
A venn diagram is a simple tool for explaining to a patient in plain language the overlap between risk factors, consequences, and comorbidities.
A venn diagram, sometimes referred to as a set diagram or a logic diagram, is a visual representation of all logical relationships between a finite number of distinct sets.

questions.text: Which of these studies is the best for evaluating exposure and outcome?
questions.solution:
Cohort study is best to evaluate exposure and outcome, especially for rare exposures.
In cohort study, cases and control groups are compared after following over a period of time. However, (randomized) clinical trial may be best to study treatment intervention and outcome after randomized groups are formed with control/intervention arms.
 
  • A cohort study is a type of research study design in which one or more samples, referred to as cohorts, are studied over time with the goal of determining which initial participant exposure characteristics (risk factors) are linked to certain diseases or outcomes.
  • Results from individuals in each cohort are measured throughout the study, and connections with particular traits are identified.
  • It proceeds from 'cause to effect'.
Note : On the other hand, a case-control study begins with the disease, moving from "effect to cause."

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 83.

questions.text: A researcher randomly chose samples from a population and plotted their means on a line graph. This distribution is referred to as:
questions.solution:
The probability distribution of a particular statistic based on a random sample is known as a sampling distribution or finite-sample distribution in statistics.
Three different distribution types are:
  • A sample distribution is an observed distribution of the values that a variable is seen to have for a sample of individuals.
  • A population distribution is a theoretical representation of the range of values that a variable can assume within a population of people.
  • A sampling distribution is a theoretical distribution of the values that a given sample statistic assumes across all feasible samples of a particular size.
Reference: High-Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 15.

questions.text: Some medications are labeled store in a cool environment only'. At what temperature should these medications be stored?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) 8–15 °C

Any temperature below 8 °C, typically between 2 and 8 °C, is considered Cold.
Cool: a temperature range of 8 to 25 °C. 
Room temperature: Average temperature in a workspace.
Warm: Between 30 and 40 °C 
Excessively hot: Any temperature over 40 °C 

Online Reference: Khuluza F, Chiumia FK, Nyirongo HM, Kateka C, Hosea RA, Mkwate W. Temperature variations in pharmaceutical storage facilities and knowledge, attitudes, and practices of personnel on proper storage conditions for medicines in southern Malawi. Front Public Health. 2023 Sep 22;11:1209903. doi: 10.3389/fpubh.2023.1209903. PMID: 37808988; PMCID: PMC10556513.

questions.text: The mean systolic blood pressure was measured in a sample population of elderly females and came out to be 125 mm Hg with a standard deviation of 10. 95 percent of people would have blood pressure above:
questions.solution:
Confidence Intervals
C = Confidence coefficient
= 1 for 68% confidence interval
= 1.96 for 95% confidence interval
= 2.58 for 99% confidence interval
= 3.29 for 99.9% confidence interval
This suggests that the range between Mean - 2 SD and Mean + 2 SD covers 95% of the population.
A value less than Mean - 2 SD will be found in about 2.5% of the population. (Or, 5% divided equally on both sides.)

Here,
Mean = 125
SD = 10
Mean - 2SD = 145 (95% confidence interval lower limit)
Mean - SD = 135 (68% confidence interval lower limit)

The average person's blood pressure will be over 105 mm Hg in 97.5% of cases, and over 115 mm Hg in roughly 84%.
Extrapolating, 95% of people will have blood pressure that is in between 105 and 115 mm Hg i.e. 110 mm Hg.


Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 36.

questions.text: What does a medication that doesn't treat an illness but instead lessens its symptoms and prolongs survival lead to?
questions.solution:
• Prevalence: Percentage of a population that has a condition at a certain period of time, and it depends on the average length of the disease as well as the rate at which new cases are developing.
  • The rate at which new illness cases are added to the population is measured by incidence (and becoming prevalent cases).
The average sickness duration is crucial since there are only three ways to quit being a prevalent case:
  • get well,
  • move out of the population, or
  • pass away.
Prevalence is equal to (Incidence Rate) x (Average Duration of Disease)

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 70.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about randomization in clinical trials?
questions.solution:
The validity of generalized (causal) inferences in scientific investigation is known as external validity,and it is typically based on experiments and is known as experimental validity.
In other words, it refers to how broadly generalizable a study's findings are to different contexts and populations. The randomization process cannot guarantee this.
The external validity in a randomised control trial can be increased by random sampling.
Randomization procedures provide the best opportunity for achieving these objectives -
  • Minimising bias.
  • Producing a balanced comparison.
  • Quantifying errors that can be attributed to chance.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 90.

choices.text: Cashless benefit on presenting smartcard and fingerprints

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct about the Rashtriya Swasthya Bima Yojana?
questions.solution:
• The government-run Rashtriya Swasthya Bima Yojana (RSBY) is a health insurance programme for the underprivileged in India.
  • It offers cashless insurance for hospitalisation in public hospitals as well as empanelled private hospitals.
  • Every "below poverty line" family with a yellow ration card must register and pay Rs. 30 to receive a biometric smart card with their fingerprints and pictures on it.
  • This enables them to access inpatient medical care in any hospital with an empanelled facility for up to Rs 30,000 per family each year.
  • Pre-existing illnesses are covered from day one, for the head of household, spouse and up to three dependent children or parents.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 719.

questions.text:
A new mother with a 15-day-old infant who is coughing, sneezing, and feverish needs assistance. She lacks the funds to get to the local hospital.
Which national programme can aid this woman?
questions.solution:
The Indian government has started the Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK) to persuade expectant mothers who still choose to give birth at home to choose institutional births.
  • This programme hopes that states would step up and make sure that every pregnant woman in need who enters a government institution receives benefits under the JSSK.
  • The free entitlements listed below are available to expectant mothers:
  • Deliveries, C-sections, medications and supplies, diagnostics, diet during hospital stays, blood donations, transportation from home to hospitals, transportation between facilities in the event of a referral, and discharge from hospitals after a 48-hour stay.
  • Newborns with illnesses also are now covered by Free Entitlements for up to 30 days following birth.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 522.

choices.text: Presumptive treatment with chloroquine should be given
Primaquine is contraindicated in infants and pregnant women
Primaquine is to be given for 7 days in falciparum malaria

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct according to the revised 2013 WHO malaria treatment guidelines?
questions.solution:
The statement correct according to the revised 2013 WHO malaria treatment guidelines: Primaquine is contraindicated in infants and pregnant women. Quinine is given in pregnancy. 
NOTE:
Chloroquine should be administered for three days in P. vivax patients, followed by Primaquine for 14 days. Primaquine is used to stop relapses, but it shouldn't be taken by pregnant women, infants, or those people who have G6PD deficiency.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 308.

questions.text: Which of the following strains is not present in the trivalent influenza vaccine?
questions.solution:
Trivalent inactivated influenza vaccines (IIV3) are designed to protect against three strains of the influenza virus:
  • Two influenza A strains (H1N1 and H3N2) and
  • One influenza B strain
The vaccine is typically given as an injection and is recommended for various age groups, including adults and children over six months.
Annual vaccination is recommended, especially for high-risk groups such as the elderly, young children, pregnant women, and individuals with certain health conditions.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 176.

questions.text: Which is the most effective method of infection control?
questions.solution:
• Hand wash is for atleast 40-60 secs and hand rub is for atleast 20-30 secs.
    Essentials of medical microbiology 4th end Apurba Shastry. Page number 205
  • Hand washing with soap is acknowledged as a practical, affordable method for attaining good health. 
  • Handwashing consists of five easy-to-follow steps (Wet, Lather, Scrub, Rinse, Dry) to prevent the spread of respiratory and diarrheal illnesses and stay healthy.



Hand rubbing using alcohol is ineffective in situations where the hands are visibly dirty or soiled. So the best method is Hand washing.

Moments of Hand Wash

questions.text: During a football game, a 29-year-old male athlete passed away after abruptly collapsing. The following discovery was made during a gross inspection at the autopsy. His family had already had two deaths that were comparable. What is the most likely cause of his death?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

The above clinical scenario is typical of HCM. The autopsy heart also shows hypertrophied myocardium

Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM)
  • 60-70% - familial
  • Autosomal dominant (most commonly-  alpha-myosin heavy-chain mutation)
  • May cause sudden death in athletes due to ventricular arrhythmia

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient comes into your clinic complaining of chest pain that has lasted the last 24 hours and has been accompanied by perspiration and diaphoresis. The ECG results are as follows. It is 150/90 mm Hg. Which of the following is not recommended for this patient's management?
questions.solution:
This is a typical case of ST-elevation MI (STEMI).
Since the patient has come to the hospital 24 hours after the onset of symptoms, there will be no benefit from thrombolysis.

Treatment algorithm for STEMI (ACC/AHA):

questions.text: A patient who was presented to the emergency department had the following ECG recorded: What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Atrial fibrillation
 
  • AF is diagnosed by electrocardiogram (ECG), either by 12-lead standard ECG or limited lead ambulatory monitor ECG, with findings of lack of organized atrial activity (no P wave), with an irregular ventricular response.
 
  • Characterized by no observable P waves and a fluctuating RR interval, erratic QRS response.
 
  • The lack of coordinated atrial activity and the irregularly irregular ventricular response define the ECG in AF.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1903, 1904.

questions.text: Which of the following medications is not recommended for the treatment of the disease seen in the ECG below?
questions.solution:
• The ECG displays baseline variation and no P waves. Atrial Fibrillation exhibits this.
  • Except for adenosine, which is used in PSVT, Rest all of these medications are utilized in AF. 
  • Acute rate control can be achieved with beta blockers and/or the calcium channel blockers verapamil and diltiazem administered either intravenously or orally, as warranted by the urgency of the clinical situation.
  • Digoxin has been used for many years for rate control, particularly in patients susceptible to congestive heart failure, because it lacks the negative inotropic effect seen in calcium channel blockers and beta blockers.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1905.

choices.text: Urine protein levels range from 30 mg/d to 300 mg/d
It is an independent risk factor for cardiovascular morbidity in diabetic patients

questions.text: Which of the following medications is incorrect about microalbuminuria?
questions.solution:
• Microalbuminuria cannot  be detected using routine dipstick tests as they are insensitive to low levels of albumin in urine.
 
  • Routine dipstick methods typically detect higher concentrations of protein, and may not be sensitive enough to detect microalbuminuria, but some specialized dipstick tests or laboratory tests may be able to detect.
 
  • Microalbuminuria is beneath detection by urinary dipstick protein analysis. Any detectable albuminuria on dipstick is called overt proteinuria and when detected at the highest level on the strip is consistent with Nephrotic range proteinuria.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2282.

questions.text: Which of the following has recently been approved as a treatment for multidrug resistant tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Bedaquiline
 
  • The FDA granted bedaquiline approval on December 28, 2012. It is specially approved to treat multi-drug-resistant tuberculosis and was the first novel treatment to treat TB in more than 40 years.
  • The ATP synthase proton pump is impacted by bedaquiline. All other quinolone antibiotics target DNA gyrase; this method does not.
  • Recently BPaLM regime is recommended for treatment of drug-resistant TB by Ministry of Health and Family Welfare.

  • BPaLM regimen consisting of four-drug combination – Bedaquiline, Pretomanid, Linezolid and Moxifloxacin, has been proven to be safe, more effective and a quicker treatment option than the previous MDR-TB treatment procedure.
     

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 822.
Recent Update: https://www.mohfw.gov.in/?q=/press-info/7673

questions.text: The WHO recommends that latent TB should be ruled out in all of the following circumstances, with the exception of which one
questions.solution:
LATENT TB INFECTION: 

State of persistent immune response to stimulation by Mycobacterium tuberculosis antigens without evidence of clinically manifested active TB. 
Latent TB should be ruled out before treatment with TNF-alpha inhibitors, in patients of silicosis and patients undergoing hemodialysis among the provided options. As these conditions can cause reactivation of TB. 


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1379.

questions.text: Chronic sinusitis, nasopharyngeal ulcers, cavitary lung nodules, and renal failure are all present in a 65-year-old male adult patient. What should the next diagnostic step be?
questions.solution:
This is a classical description of Granulomatosis with Polyangitis a.k.a Wegener's Granulomatosis.
  • cANCA levels are required for diagnosis.
 
  • GPA is characterized by glomerulonephritis and granulomatous vasculitis of the upper and lower respiratory tracts.
 
  • Additionally, disseminated vasculitis in varying degrees that affects both small arteries and veins may manifest.
ANCA Memorizing trick:- 
PCM- p-ANCA- Churg's Strauss, Microscopic polyangitis 
c-ANCA- Wegener's 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2806, 2807.

HbeAg-Non-reactive

questions.solution:
State of recovery from chronic hepatitis

questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient was seen with a history of back discomfort, which was worse in the morning and was helped by taking a warm bath. What is the most likely next finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
• The clinical scenario in the above question with morning stiffness is character­istic of spondyloarthropathy, like AS.
  • The initial symptom is pain that can be either sharp or dull, insidious in onset, felt deep in the lower lumbar or gluteal region, and accompanied by low-back morning stiffness of up to a few hours’ duration that improves with activity and returns following inactivity.
 
  • Such patients also commonly have  decreased chest wall expansion. 
  • Chest expansion is measured as the difference between maximal inspiration and maximal forced expiration at the levels of either the fourth intercostal space or the xiphisternum, with the patient’s hands resting on or just behind the head. Normal chest expansion is ≥2.5 cm. The value is less than 2.5 cm in SpA.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2793.

questions.text: Which one of these is a new oral medication used to treat chronic Hepatitis C?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Ledipasvir

Ledipasvir is an Inhibitor of NS5A protein. 
Commonly used in combination with sofosbuvir for treatment in chronic hepatitis C genotype I patients. 
Standard treatment regimen for Hep C - Sofosbuvir + Velpatasvir x 12 weeks
Other options: -
  • Interferon alpha and Lamivudine are used in the treatment of chronic Hepatitis B 
  • Oseltamivir is used in the treatment of Influenza
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 859.

questions.text: What does a lack of urobilinogen in the urine indicate in a jaundice patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Obstructive jaundice
 
  • In obstructive jaundice, urobilinogen levels are typically decreased or absent in urine.
  • This occurs because the obstruction prevents conjugated bilirubin from entering the intestines, where it would normally be converted to urobilinogen by gut bacteria and then excreted in urine.
           
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2650.

questions.text: Which is the most specific sign of metabolic encephalopathy?
questions.solution:
Although asterixis on the motor examination is vague, it typically points to a toxic or metabolic cause of the delirium.

It is a disorder of motor control, defined as sudden, brief, arrhythmic lapses of sustained posture due to involuntary interruption in muscle contraction.
This condition involves a specific form of negative myoclonus, characterized by momentary loss of muscle tone in agonist muscles, followed by a compensatory jerk involving antagonistic muscles
 
  • Bilateral asterixis is a sure symptom of metabolic encephalopathy or drug intoxication in a sleepy and disoriented patient.
  • However, Most common symptom of Metabolic encephalopathy is Delirium.
Other symptoms include:
  • Hallucinations
  • Involuntary movements (tremors)
  • Seizures
  • Difficulty breathing
  • Loss of consciousness
  • Nausea
  • Fatigue and difficulty sleeping (insomnia)
  • Depression 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 186.
Agarwal, R, and R Baid. “Asterixis.” Journal of postgraduate medicine vol. 62,2 (2016): 115-7. doi:10.4103/0022-3859.180572. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4944342/

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of glucocorticoid deficiency?
questions.solution:
Diabetes is NOT a feature of Glucocorticoid deficiency as glucocorticoids cause hyperglycemia. Rest all are features of Glucocorticoid deficiency.

questions.text: In which of the following aphasias naming and fluency are impaired?
questions.solution:
Broca's aphasia:
Preserved comprehension (except grammar) with impaired naming and fluency. 
Brocas aphasia is caused  due to damage to the inferior frontal lobe of the brain's dominant hemisphere, made up of Brodmann areas 44 and 45.

questions.text: A 9-year-old child complained of having trouble combing his hair and climbing stairs. on examination bilateral calves were enlarged. His mother also gave a history that the child has been toe walking since a few days. What comes next in the diagnostic process?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Creatine kinase levels

The above mentioned clinical features points to a diagnosis of Proximal myopathy most probably associated with Duchenne Muscular dystrophy (DMD).

Clinical features include: 
  • Proximal muscles, especially of the lower extremities, are prominently involved.
  • This becomes evident in DMD very early; boys with DMD have difficulty climbing stairs and never run well.
  • As the disease progresses, weakness becomes more generalized. Hypertrophy of muscles, particularly in the calves, is an early and prominent finding.

 
  • The initial preferred muscle enzyme to evaluate when assessing myopathies is Creatine Kinase (CK) levels.
  • The CK leaks from the muscle fibre to the serum as a result of muscle damage.
  • CK is the most sensitive measure of muscle damage. The MM isoenzyme predominates in skeletal muscle, whereas CK-myocardial bound (CK-MB) is the marker for cardiac muscle.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3520, 3521.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of benign intracranial hypertension?
questions.solution:
Graves disease exhibits proptosis. Benign intracranial hypertension does not exhibit it.

Benign Intracranial Hypertension:  (a.k.a Pseudotumor cerebri)
  • Adult idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH) is a rare condition of unknown cause, which results in raised intracranial pressure (ICP).
  •  Young obese women are most commonly affected, although rarely it may occur in men.
  • Patients first experience headaches, diplopia (typically from CN VI palsy), and unaltered mental status.
  • A diagnosis of IIH requires CSF opening pressure greater than 250 mmCSF



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 116.

questions.text: What does this crystal from a urine analysis stand for?
questions.solution:
Calcium oxalate crystals have a distinctive 'X' mark and are square in shape. They are typically described as “Envelope shaped” stones.
  • Struvite stones resemble the lid of a coffin.
  • Uric acid crystals can form rosettes and are frequently needle-shaped.
  • Hexagonal crystals make up cystine.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2370.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old patient was diagnosed with intussusception, which required surgery and the removal of a section of his intestine that had several polyps.
Pathology was visible using microscopy as follows: What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Hamartomatous polyps 
 
  • The histology shows a sizable, large, pedunculated polyp with a distinct lobulated shape.
  • Well-developed smooth muscle and an arborizing network of connective tissue are seen to extend into the polyp, and it's surrounded by normal intestinal epithelium rich in goblet cells.
  • This is typical of PJ syndrome (Peutz-Jegher syndrome) which has hamartomatous polyps. 
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 808.

questions.text: What causes Peau d'Orange in breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Obstruction of sub-dermal lymphatics
 
  • The phenomenon known as "peau d' orange" is brought on by lymphatic blockage in locally advanced breast cancer. It indicates that the skin is involved (T4b Stage).
  • The reason for "peau d' orange" is cutaneous lymphatic edema.
  • The infiltrated skin cannot swell where the sweat ducts are attached, giving the area an orange-like appearance. A similar phenomenon can occasionally be observed over a chronic abscess.


Fig: Peau d’orange (skin of the orange) or edema of the skin of the breast.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 815.

questions.text: A patient underwent thyroid surgery for hyperthyroidism. He manifested thyroid storm symptoms two days later. Which is the most likely cause
questions.solution:
Thyrotoxic Crisis (Storm)
This is an acute exacerbation of hyperthyroidism.
  • It occurs if a thyrotoxic patient has been inadequately prepared for thyroidectomy and is now extremely rare.
  • Very rarely, a thyrotoxic patient presents in a crisis and this may follow an unrelated operation.
  • Symptomatic and supportive treatment is for dehydration, hyperpyrexia, and restlessness.
  • This requires cooling the patient with ice packs, the administration of oxygen, diuretics for cardiac failure, digoxin for uncontrolled atrial fibrillation, sedation, and intravenous hydrocortisone.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 866.

questions.text: Progressive jaundice, pruritus, and clay-colored feces had been observed in a 60-year-old habitual smoker for two months. There was a history of jaundice rising and waning. The major pancreatic duct and common bile duct were shown to be dilated by a CT scan. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Periampullary Carcinoma.

Historically, evaluation and management of cholangiocarcinoma required arbitrary division of the bile duct into thirds based on the location of obstruction. Lesions of the middle third, however, are decidedly rare, so investigations have recently focused on perihilar and intrahepatic lesions, known as proximal lesions, versus those involving the periampullary region, known as distal disease. More than two thirds of all cholangiocarcinomas involve the proximal biliary tree near the bifurcation, known as a Klatskin tumor.

It often presents with obstructive jaundice due to obstruction of the bile ducts, leading to symptoms such as Waxing and wanning Jaundice( periampullary cancer causes obstruction, later by the fluid pressure of bile a part of tumor is released causing waning of jaundice and the cycle repeats), itching (pruritus), and pale stools (acholic stools).

With hilar cholangio-carcinomas, the gallbladder and visualized extrahepatic biliary tree are usually decompressed, whereas distal lesions will have extrahepatic biliary ductal dilation and gallbladder distention.

Frequently, dilatation of both the bile and pancreatic ducts (“double-duct sign”) On CT scan.


Fig: Double duct sign of Periampullary CA.

Reference: Sleisenger and Fordtran’s Gastrointestinal and Liver Disease, 10th Edition, Page No 1197.

choices.text: Remnant of proximal part of vitellointestinal duct

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Meckel's diverticulum is false?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Present in 3% of the population

Meckel's diverticulum is present in 2% of people rather than 3% of the population.

* [Extra Edge]: Features of Meckel’s diverticulum:

  • Remnant of vitellointestinal duct.
  • Occurs in 2% of patients, 5 cm (2 inches) long, 60 cm (2 feet) from the ileocaecal valve, 20% heterotopic epithelium
  • Should be looked for when a normal appendix is found at surgery for suspected appendicitis
  • If a Meckel’s diverticulum is found incidentally at surgery, it can be left provided it has a wide mouth and is not thickened
  • Can be a source of gastrointestinal bleeding if it contains ectopic gastric mucosa

Fig: Meckel’s diverticulum

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1311.

choices.text: The hernia lies above and medial to pubic tubercle
This type of hernia is most common in children

questions.text: A child came in with a swelling in the right groin area. A gurgling sound appeared when the swelling subsided. Which of the following statements is incorrect?
questions.solution:
The incorrect statement in this scenario is:

1. The sac contains omentum only.

Given that the child has a swelling in the right groin area, and a gurgling sound is heard when the swelling subsides, the most likely diagnosis is an indirect inguinal hernia
Hernia sac in an indirect inguinal hernia can contain not just omentum but also bowel loops (usually small intestine). While the sac may contain omentum, it more commonly contains loops of the intestine, and in some cases, both omentum and bowel

An inguinal hernia can be differentiated from a femoral hernia by ascertaining the relation of the neck of the sac to the medial end of the inguinal ligament and the pubic tubercle, i.e. in the case of an inguinal hernia the neck is above and medial, whereas that of a femoral hernia is below and lateral.
Whereas the neck of the indirect hernia is lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels, the direct hernia usually emerges medial to this except in the saddle bag or pantaloon type, which has both a lateral and a medial component.
An indirect hernia travels down the canal on the outer (lateral and anterior) side of the spermatic cord.
A direct hernia comes out directly forward through the posterior wall of the inguinal canal.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1060.

questions.text:
Accidentally, a stapler was positioned below and lateral to the iliopubic tract during laparoscopic inguinal hernia surgery.
Following surgery, the patient reported thigh pain and soreness. This is due to the involvement of:
questions.solution:
The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is located below and lateral to the iliopubic tract and is highly likely to be injured during laparoscopic hernia repair.


Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1070.

questions.text: Which of these is the most dependable for monitoring fluid resuscitation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Urine output

The easiest and most reliable method of assessing the adequacy of fluid resuscitation is by monitoring the urine output. 

The key to monitoring of resuscitation is urine output. Urine output should be between 0.5 and 1.0 mL/kg body weight per hour. If the urine output drops and the patient is showing signs of hypoperfusion (tachycardia, cool peripheries and a high lactate/metabolic acidosis), then a bolus of 10 mL/kg body weight should be given. It is important that patients are not over-resuscitated; urine output in excess of 2 mL/kg body weight per hour should warrant a decrease in infusion.

Other measures of tissue perfusion such as lactate levels can be useful, particularly in larger burns. A persistent raised lactate/metabolic acidosis can indicate a missed systemic toxicity from cyanide or carbon monoxide. Patients with underlying comorbidities, particularly cardiac or renal, will require further intensive monitoring such as central venous pressure measurement in an intensive care setting.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 671.

questions.text: What are the minimum and maximum Glasgow Coma Score values?
questions.solution:
The minimum score possible is E1V1M1
1(eye)+1(verbal)+1(motor)=3

Maximum score possible is E4V5M6 
4+5+6=15

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 369.

questions.text: During surgery, a patient went into class 3 hemorrhagic shock due to an accidental injury to a critical vessel. Which cannula size should be used for immediate fluid resuscitation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) 16 Gauge

Amongst the given options - option (1) - 16 Gauge is the best answer.
In a patient with massive bleeding, there is always a risk of the patient going into shock and the widest bore cannula available showed be used for cannulation.
The ATLS guidelines recommend securing intravenous access with two large-bore cannulas (14-16G) in a patient needing resuscitation. 



Reference: ATLS® Advanced Trauma Life Support®, American College of Surgeons, 10th Edition, Page No 52.

questions.text: A female patient aged 28, who also had dysmenorrhea, appeared with lower abdomen pain. Laparoscopic examination revealed the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis
questions.solution:
Chocolate cyst
  • It is brought on by endometriosis and develops when a microscopic patch of endometrial tissue, which is the mucous membrane that lines the interior of the uterine wall, bleeds, sheds, gets transplanted, and grows and enlarges inside the ovaries.
  • Over the course of months and years, the blood thickens and turns brown. When it ruptures, the substance leaks onto the surface of the uterus, bladder, intestine, and the corresponding gaps between them, as well as into the pelvis.
  • In other cases given in option there would be bulky ovaries. 

Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1802.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient in labor had the following fetal tocographic finding: What does it imply?
questions.solution:
Late Deceleration suggestive of utero placental insufficiency leading to fetal distress
   

Remember all the types and causes of decelerations . Frequently repeated question


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 452.

questions.text: What can be seen in the HSG image below?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is genital TB as areas of blocked/constricted fallopian tubes are seen in the HSG.
It is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
Infection almost always results from spread from an extragenital source, usually from a hematogenous source or less commonly, via lymphatic vessels or from the peritoneal cavity.


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 217, 351.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct about Swyer syndrome?
questions.solution:
Can be fertile with ovum donation 

Because women with Swyer syndrome lack ovaries, they are infertile.
However, they can become pregnant through the implantation of donated eggs.

XY gonadal dysgenesis, also known as Swyer syndrome, is a type of hypogonadism in a person whose karyotype is 46,XY. Though they typically have normal female external genitalia, the person has functionless gonads, fibrous tissue termed “streak gonads”, and if left untreated, will not experience puberty. Such gonads are typically surgically removed (as they have a significant risk of developing cancer)

The typical medical treatment is hormone replacement therapy.


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 112, 141.

questions.text: Which of these symptoms characterises Asherman syndrome?
questions.solution:
Scar tissue builds up inside the uterus and/or cervix, causing Asherman syndrome (intrauterine adhesions or synechiae). The infective causes of these adhesions are schistosomiasis and TB, with dilatation and curettage(Most common), and uterine surgery being other causes.
Clinical Features are
1. Infertility
2.Amennorrhea
3. Hypomenorrhea

Oligomenorrhea is when the no of days after which mens occurs is delayed. It is seen in PCOS. 


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 123,147.

questions.solution:
Genital tuberculosis

Chlamydia and Gonorrhoea will lead to PID which will be seen as hydrosalpinx

Endometriosis shows ' low level ground glass ' echogenicities and kissing ovaries appearance on USG

HSG FINDINGS OF GENITAL TB
Genital TB Highly Communicable In Senile
People and Healthy Living.
