G-GOLF CLUB TUBE
T-TOBACCO POUCH
B-BEADED TUBE
C-CORNUAL BLOCKS
I-INTRAVASATION OF DYE
P-PSEUDOUNICORNUATE UTERUS
H-HONEY COMB UTERUS
L-LEAD PIPE TUBES



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 351.

questions.text: Which of the following is a menopausal diagnostic sign?
questions.solution:
Menopause is the time in most women's lives when menstruation ends permanently. Usually, menopause starts between the ages of 45 and 55.

 Criteria for Menopause:

1. Estrogen (E2) low at 10-20 pg/ml
2. Estrone (El)- 30-70 pg/ml
3. E2/El < 1
4. Serum FSH > 40 IU/L


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 86, 87.

questions.text: What is the first sign of puberty seen in girls?
questions.solution:
• The first physical sign of puberty in girls is typically a firm, tender lump under the center of one or both breasts, which appears on average at around 10.5 years. This is referred to as thelarche.
The sequence of puberty in males and females is given below

Girls: TPM
1. Thelarche
2. Pubarche
3. Menarche

Boys: TPAM
1. Testicular enlargement
2. Pubarche
3. Adrenarche
4. Moustache and Beard


Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 9 th Page No 284,285,286

choices.text: Any time as soon as she presents to the clinic irrespective of pregnancy

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman with a seizure illness who is using antiepileptic medications gets married. When should the patient be encouraged to take folic acid supplements?
questions.solution:
• Folic acid supplementation is recommended for women with seizure disorders who are taking antiepileptic medications because these medications can interfere with the absorption of folate.
  • To reduce the risk of neural tube defects in offspring, women should start taking folic acid supplements three months before becoming pregnant.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 735.

questions.text: Which is the shortest anteroposterior diameter in the pelvic inlet?
questions.solution:
• The obstetric conjugate is the shortest anteroposterior diameter of the pelvic inlet.
  • It is measured from the midpoint of the sacral promontory to the posterior aspect of the pubic symphysis.
  • It is important in obstetrics as it determines whether the fetal head can pass through the pelvic inlet during childbirth.



Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 100.

questions.text: In the first two months of pregnancy, what produces the hormones estrogen and progesterone?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Corpus luteum
 
  • hCG secretion maintains the corpus luteum for the first trimester of pregnancy. During this time the corpus luteum maintains the pregnant state by secreting estradiol and progesterone.
  • By the beginning of 2nd trimester, the placenta becomes competent to secrete enough estrogen and progesterone to sustain the pregnancy. hCG secretion tapers off and the corpus luteum becomes nonfunctional.
  • During the first 2 to 4 weeks or pregnancy, rising hCG levels maintain production of estradiol in the corpus luteum. Ovarian production of both progesterone and estrogens drops significantly by the 7th week of pregnancy.


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 101, 176.

questions.text: Which is the preferred medication for pregnancy-induced hypertension?
questions.solution:
Alpha-methyldopa is commonly recommended for the treatment of hypertension during pregnancy due to its safety profile and effectiveness in reducing blood pressure without negatively affecting fetal development.
Other medications like Atenolol, Nitroprusside, and Enalapril are generally contraindicated or less preferred during pregnancy due to potential adverse effects on the fetus.
 
  • Atenolol is not recommended because of its link with fetal-growth restriction. (Option 1)
  • Labetalol is an α/β-adrenergic blocker that is considered sae. Clonidine and α-methyldopa act centrally by reducing sympathetic outflow to effect a generalized decreased vascular tone. Drugs in this class most frequently used in pregnancy are methyldopa and labetalol (American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, 2018a).
  • ACE-inhibitors (Enalapril) can cause severe fetal malformations when given in the second and third trimesters. These include oligohydramnios, hypocalvaria, and renal dysfunction. (Option 4)


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 949.

questions.text: At 18 weeks gestation, a pregnant G3P2 visits the clinic for genetic counseling. She has a history of having two significant thalassemic babies. Which examination would you suggest right now?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Amniocentesis
 
  • At 18 weeks of gestation, Amniocentesis is the preferred test for diagnosing genetic disorders, including thalassemia.
  • It allows for the collection of amniotic fluid, which contains fetal cells that can be tested for thalassemia mutations.
  • Chorionic villus sampling (CVS) is typically done earlier in pregnancy (10-13 weeks), and cordocentesis is done later (after 18-20 weeks) but is more invasive and riskier.
  • Cordocentesis has some limited indications like in Rh negative pregnancy and not routinely used as diagnostic test.

Non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT) can be useful for screening >10 weeks POG, but in this case, given the history of significant thalassemic babies, a diagnostic test like amniocentesis is more appropriate.




Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 346.

questions.text: What does modified BPP consist of?
questions.solution:
The modified BPP 
Nonstress test + evaluation of the amount of amniotic fluid (AFI)
It's considered abnormal if NST is non reactive or AFI is less than 5.




Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 390, 391.

questions.text: Which of these does not use levonorgestrel for purposes other than contraception?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Premenstrual tension
 
  • In premenstrual tension combined OCPs are used instead of Levonorgestrel.
  • In all other cases Levonorgestrel is used.
  • Severe premenstrual syndrome requires suppression of ovulation by combined estrogen-progesterone treatment given cyclically. Relatively higher dose of progestin is generally used.
  • Ovarian suppression with GnRH agonist may be required in nonresponsive cases. Progestins are added to estrogen when it is used for severe dysmenorrhoea.
     
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 344.
Online Reference:
InformedHealth.org [Internet]. Cologne, Germany: Institute for Quality and Efficiency in Health Care (IQWiG); 2006-. Premenstrual syndrome: Learn More – Treatment for PMS. [Updated 2022 May 18]. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK279264/

questions.text: Which of the following cannot be used for post-coital contraception?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1)  Desogestrel 

After having sex, women may use emergency contraception (EC), sometimes known as emergency postcoital contraception, to avoid becoming pregnant.
Desogestrel is not as an emergency contraceptive.

Emergency Contraception Methods:
1. Progestin-only Pill-0.75 mg levonorgestrel 2 doses 12 hours apart with 72 hours
2. Copper-containing IUD within 5 days
3. Combined oral contraceptive pills that can be used for emergency contraception when taken in multiple doses 12-24 hours apart, within 72 hours.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 347.

questions.text: What exactly is an ulipristal acetate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answers is (Option 4) Selective progesterone receptor modulator
 
  • Ulipristal acetate exerts its pharmacological activity by binding to the body’s progesterone receptors to produce an anti-progesterone contraceptive effect on the ovary (by suppressing or delaying ovulation) and on the endometrium (by decreasing endometrial thickness).
  • It inhibits ovulation by suppressing LH surge as well as by direct effect on follicular rupture. In addition, its action on endometrium can interfere with implantation.
  • In clinical trials the efficacy of ulipristal (30 mg) as emergency contraceptive has been rated equal to that of levonorgestrel (1.5 mg) when taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse, and to be more effective when taken between 72–120 hours.
  • Thus, it may have an advantage, if the woman misses to take the drug within 72 hours.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 346.

questions.text: What misoprostol dosage is recommended for the urgent treatment of postpartum hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Misoprostol is commonly administered orally or sublingually at a dose of 600 mcg to manage postpartum hemorrhage due to its uterotonic effects, which help to reduce bleeding after childbirth.
 
  • Misoprostol is a synthetic prostaglandin E1 analogue.
  • If Misoprostol is used to treat atony, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (2019a) recommends a dose of 600 to 1000 μg rectally, orally, or sublingually.


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 736.

questions.text: When is the ideal time to give anti-D to a patient who is pregnant?
questions.solution:
28 weeks
  • Routine antenatal antiD prophylaxis is usually not administered until 28 weeks’ gestation, since transplacental haemorrhages large enough to cause sensitisation do not usually occur until the third trimester and thus Rhesus antibodies usually develop after the 28th week of gestation.
  • A second dose is repeated 72 hours after delivery.

Reference-Williams Obstetrics 26th edition Page no 190

questions.text: In the image below, which of the following congenital defects can be seen?
questions.solution:
The figure shows a skin-covered, brilliantly transilluminate defect in the back in a newborn. This is typical of a meningocele.
  • Meninges herniate through a gap in the posterior vertebral arches and result in a meningocele.
  • Although tethering, syringomyelia, or diastematomyelia may occur, the spinal cord often assumes a normal position in the spinal canal and is in a normal state.
  • Along the vertebral column, typically in the low back, is a fluctuant midline mass that may transilluminate.

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No  3066,3067

questions.text: At 2:30 a.m., a 2-year-old child who had been coughing (cough was barking-like) for the previous two days was reported to the pediatric emergency room. On inspection, the patient's temperature was 39 °C, and the only time stridor was audible was when the patient was crying. There was no additional abnormality discovered. Which is the most appropriate management in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is option(1)
The scenario described above(barking cough with stridor) is diagnostic of laryngotracheobronchitis (LTB) or croup. Hence, Dexa­methasone will be the treatment of choice.

Other options
  • Option 2 -Racemic epinephrine can be added for symptomatic relief in moderate/severe LTB but it is not the management of choice. Drug of choice is always Dexamethasone.
  • Option 4- IV Antibiotics are indicated for Epiglottitis. LTB is a viral disease(caused by parainfluenza or influenza virus) - hence, antibiotics are not indicated. 


Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 376,377

questions.text:
For the past six days, a 1-year old baby has experienced 10 to 12 episodes of watery stools per day.
What additional medications should be given to the infant in addition to the zinc supplements?
questions.solution:
• The infant here suffers from acute diarrhea and treatment includes oral rehydration therapy, zinc supplementation, and continued breastfeeding.


 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 289-292

questions.text: Which of the following is deficient in milk?
questions.solution:
Milk is a rich source of calcium, protein, vitamin A, phosphorus, and saturated fats. However, it is naturally deficient in vitamin D and vitamin K. 
Hence, a newborn is given Inj Vit K at birth and takes Vit d drops (400IU/day) for 1st year of life. 

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 592.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a criteria for severe acute malnutrition in a 7-month-old child?
questions.solution:
World Health Organization (WHO) and UNICEF define severe acute malnutrition (SAM) in children 6 to 59 months of age as one or more of the following:

1. A weight-to-height ratio that is less than three standard deviations (SD/Z scores) from the average WHO growth reference. (W/L <-3SD)
2. Bipedal nutritional edema is present, or
3. Mid upper arm circumference is less than 11.5 cm.

Height for age is used as an indicator for chronic malnutrition, not SAM. If H/A <-2SD - child is said to have stunting or chronic malnutrition. 




Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 336

questions.text: How is the term "wasting" defined?
questions.solution:
The term malnutrition addresses 3 broad groups of conditions:

1. Wasting (low weight- for-height/length) aka Acute Malnutrition
2. Stunting (low height-for-age) aka Chronic Malnutrition
3. Underweight (low weight-for-age)

The term "wasting" is another term for Acute Malnutrition which is defined as weight for height being less than -2SD. 






Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 St Page No 333,334, table 57.2

choices.text: 5-kg male baby delivered at term experiences respiratory difficulty shortly after birth and needs artificial ventilation.

questions.text:
After a straightforward pregnancy and delivery, a 3.5-kg male baby delivered at term experiences respiratory difficulty shortly after birth and needs artificial ventilation.
The lung fields on the chest radiograph appear like diffuse ground glass, despite the normal cardiothymic silhouette. Replacement of the surfactant does not
enhance gas exchange. The hypoxemia gets worse throughout the first week of life. Both echocardiographic findings and routing culture results are negative.
A female sibling who had respiratory trouble passed away at the age of one month. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical history suggestive of no response to surfactant therapy and a family history of sibling death points towards a diagnosis of pulmonary alveolar proteinosis.
  • Pulmonary Alveolar Proteinosis (PAP) is characterized by pulmonary surfactant building up intra-alveolarly.
  • A granular, eosinophilic substance that is diastase-resistant and stains positively with periodic acid-Schiff reagent occupying the distal air spaces is seen on histopathologic examination.


 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 2304

questions.text: Which deformity is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
• A hallux valgus  is a fixed abduction of the first metatarsophalangeal joint of the great toe as shown in the given image. 
  • It is also known as a bunion
  • It is a common deformity of the big toe joint where the big toe deviates laterally towards the second toe, causing a bony bump to form on the inside edge of the foot

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 327

questions.text: Which of the subsequent tests is represented in the given image?
questions.solution:

  • Narath sign- Vascular sign of Narath -Positive in hip dislocations.







Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 349,350

questions.text: A 9-year-old child arrives with the malformation described below. Which fracture is most likely to cause such a defect?
questions.solution:
The given image shows cubitus varus of right upper limb and it is most commonly seen as a complication of supracondylar fracture of humerus.  
Cubitus Varus ('Gun-Stock' Deformity)
(Varus refers to a limb malformation in which a portion of the limb deviates from the body's midline.)
When the arms are raised and the elbow is extended, the deformity is most noticeable. Supracondylar fracture malunion is the most frequent cause of this condition.
Wedge osteotomy of the lower humerus can be used to repair the deformity, however it is recommended to wait until skeletal maturity.


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 102

Immediately after a trauma, a child complained of forearm ache. The results of an AP and lateral X-ray of the forearm are displayed in the picture below.

questions.text: What is the cause of meralgia paresthetica?
questions.solution:
• Numbness or pain in the outer thigh, known as meralgia paresthetica, is most commonly brought on by damage to the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve of the thigh.
  • The area where it passes between the ilium and the inguinal ligament close to the attachment at the anterior superior iliac spine is where it is most frequently injured by entrapment or compression.
  • Sometimes the nerve may be damaged while doing laparoscopic hernia repair.


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 305

questions.text: Which of the following cannot cause axillary nerve damage?
questions.solution:
• Improper use of clutches causes radial nerve palsy by compressing radial nerve passing through radial groove not axillary nerve. Rest all cause axillary nerve damage. 


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 46,91
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK539895/

questions.text: Which of the following locations is affected by a lesion that results in a keyhole-shaped visual field defect?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Lateral geniculate body
 
  • Lesions involving the lateral geniculate body are frequently associated with visual field abnormalities that resemble Keyholes.
  • The coloboma of the iris can be observed if the question just asks about a keyhole-shaped defect and not a visual field defect.

Keyhole shaped defects:
  • Keyhole shape visual field defect: lesion at Lateral Geniculate Body
  • Keyhole vision with macular sparring: lesion at Occipital lobe.
  • Keyhole shape defect: Coloboma of Iris.





Reference: Luco, C et al. “Visual field defects in vascular lesions of the lateral geniculate body.” Journal of neurology, neurosurgery, and psychiatry vol. 55,1 (1992): 12-5. doi:10.1136/jnnp.55.1.12. URL: https://jnnp.bmj.com/content/55/1/12

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common fungal eye  infections in HIV-positive patients ?
questions.solution:
• The most frequent fungus infection seen in HIV patients is candidemia.
  • As a significant nosocomial pathogen, Candida albicans is the most prevalent species.
  • Keratitis, conjunctivitis, and endogenous fungal endophthalmitis are all most frequently brought on by it.
 
  • Predisposing conditions include diabetes, intravenous drug use, prolonged hospitalization, history of major surgery, bacterial sepsis requiring broad-spectrum systemic antibiotics, hyperalimentation, chronic indwelling catheters, and immunosuppression secondary to organ transplantation, chemotherapy or acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS).
 
  • Aspergillus infection is reported in immunocompetent patients without predisposing condition. HIV-AIDS is generally NOT a predisposing factor.
  • Toxoplasma and Rhinosporidium both are Protozoa.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 734, 735.

choices.text: Stapes defect with fixation of footplate and lenticular process involvement

questions.text: What kind of congenital ossicular dysfunction is more typical?
questions.solution:
Congenital Stapes Anomalies with Normal Eardrum:
Incus and stapes anomalies > isolated stapes anomalies > anomalies in all 3 ossicles.
Among stapes anomalies: Stapes footplate fixation only > Mobile stapes footplate with other anomalies> Stapes footplate fixation with other anomalies > Isolated stapes defect.
 A nonprogressive and conductive hearing loss with the normal eardrum, but no history of trauma and infection, is highly suggestive of a congenital ossicular malformation.
Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Head and Neck surgery ,7th Edition - page 97

questions.text: Which of the following hearing impairments benefits the most from the use of audio neurotherapy?
questions.solution:
The vestibular system of the inner ear is only involved in Meniere's illness. Thus, a Neurotherapy i.e. a direct nerve stimulation will only be effective in Meniere's illness. A shift in the labyrinth's fluid volume is what causes this inner ear condition.

Reference :https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/37838094/

questions.text: Which of the following tests is advised for newborn hearing screening?
questions.solution:
National Deafness Programme recommends OAE as a screening method for hearing assessment
It is not the investigation of choice which is ABR/BERA
 
Usually, a two-step screening process is used where those infants which fail in OAE are subjected to BERA/ABR


Types of OAE
 

Types of OAE Definition Remarks
Spontaneous OAE Sounds emitted spontaneously ie without a stimulus Seen in 20-75% neonates and their absence doesn't dignify abnormality
Transient Evoked OAE Sounds emitted to a stimulus of very small duration Used for Screening.
Distortion product OAE Sounds emitted to 2 simultaneous tones but of different frequencies

Used for early detection of cochlear damage (especially for noise-induced damage/ototoxicity)

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Head and Neck surgery ,7th Edition - page 29

questions.text: A patient arrives at a clinic to have their hearing checked. With the Weber test lateralized to the right ear, Rinne's test reveals air conduction to be stronger than bone conduction on both sides. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Weber's test lateralization to the right indicates either right conductive deafness or left sensorineural deafness. Now in conductive deafness, BC is better than AC in Rinnie's test, hence the patient probably has sensorineural deafness involving the left ear, as per the findings of Rinnie and Weber tests. Schwabach's test should be carried out in this situation to determine the absolute bone conduction and to validate these results.     

           

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Head and Neck surgery ,7th Edition - page 24

questions.text:
A woman approaches with a history of experiencing burning after eating spicy meals. On inspection, the buccal mucosa has bilateral white lacy streaks.
Although the third molar is amalgamated, there is no history of tobacco addiction. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
White lacy lines (Wickham's striae) with a history of amalgamated molar is suggestive of Lichen planus.
               
Lichen Planus
 

  • Cutaneous lesions of lichen planus consist of itchy, violaceous, flat-topped papules that may coalesce focally to form plaques
  • It is also referred to as pruritic, purple, polygonal papules
  • These papules are often highlighted by white dots or lines called 'Wickham striae', representing the clinical correlates of zones of hypergranulosis, that typify lesions histologically.
  • Multiple lesions are characteristic and are symmetrically distributed; particularly on the extremities, often about the wrists and elbow, and on the glans penis

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 247

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman has had asymptomatic dome-shaped, tiny lesions on her forehead for two months. Her 2-year-old daughter suffers from comparable lesions.
Which is the lesion's causative agent?
questions.solution:
• The pearly white papule lesions on the forehead are most likely Molluscum contagiosum, which is brought on by the poxvirus and has a history of being passed down to daughters:
  • Molluscum contagiosum (MC), often known as water warts, is a viral infection of the skin or mucous membranes that is brought on by the molluscum virus, a DNA poxvirus (MCV)
  • The lesions of molluscum contagiosum have a flesh-colored, dome-shaped, and pearly look. 
  • They are often 1-5 mm in diameter, with an umbilicated center.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 25.12, 25.13

questions.text:
A young man with an anesthetic patch on his right forearm arrived.
On examination, a thicker nerve was palpable.
This image comes from a skin biopsy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The patient has presented with a single anesthetic patch and single enlarged nerve, and a well defined granuloma can be seen on the skin biopsy.
  • These findings are typical of Tuberculoid Leprosy.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 28.7, 28.8

questions.text:
One month after commencing anti-epileptic medication, a 28-year-old patient with neurocysticercosis begins to have universal peeling of all skin surfaces apart from the palms and soles.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The clinical description provided above is typical of toxic epidermal necrolysis and includes a history of drug use (anticonvulsant) followed by confluent skin involvement (likely to be greater than 30%).
  • Lyell's syndrome, commonly known as toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN), is a rare, potentially fatal skin disorder that is typically brought on by a medication reaction. The condition leads to a separation between the upper epidermis and the lower dermis of the skin.



Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 119.13

questions.text: Which of the following types of oral candidiasis does not have a white patch?
questions.solution:
Chronic Erythematous (atrophic) candidiasis appears as a red, raw-looking lesion instead of a white patch seen in all other types.

Types of Oral Candidiasis
  Pseudomembranous:
Acute pseudomembranous candidiasis is a classic form of oral candidiasis, commonly referred to as thrush.
 Characterized by a coating or individual patches of the pseudomembranous white slough that can be easily wiped away to reveal erythematous, and sometimes minimally bleeding mucosa beneath.
Erythematous:
Erythematous (atrophic) candidiasis is where the condition appears as a red, raw-looking lesion.
Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis:
Chronic candidal lesions on the skin, in the mouth, and on other mucous membranes (i.e. secondary oral candidiasis).
Hyperplastic:
This variant is also sometimes termed 'plaque-like candidiasis' or 'nodular candidiasis' or 'candidal leukoplakia'.
The most common appearance of hyperplastic candidiasis is a persistent white plaque that does not rub off.

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 32.62

questions.text: What is the purpose of the following instrument?
questions.solution:
The laryngoscope seen here has a curved blade and is used for direct laryngoscopy.
Most tracheal intubations are performed using a viewing device.
The most often used tool for this purpose has traditionally been the traditional laryngoscope. A set of interchangeable blades plus a handle with batteries and a light source make up the standard laryngoscope.

questions.text: The image of a pro-seal-type LMA is given below. Above what site is the A-marked area of the airway positioned?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Above esophagus
 
  • The internal gastric tube (drainage tube), which is kept immediately above the esophageal aperture to aspirate GI fluids, is indicated by the arrow.
  • A reusable supraglottic airway device called the LMA ProSealTM includes a gastric drainage tube that is positioned lateral to the main airway tube and terminates at the tip of the mask.
  • By separating the gastrointestinal and respiratory tracts, the gastric drainage tube allows regurgitated fluid to flow up the drain tube and bypass the glottis, shielding the airway from contamination in the event of passive regurgitation.



Reference: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1389-1392.

questions.text: A resident was operating on a patient when she abruptly observed the following plot on the capnograph monitor. What treatment course should be given to the patient immediately?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Increase muscle relaxant
 
  • The capnograph shown here shows " Curare clefts”. It is seen during spontaneous ventilation & cleft is seen in last third of plateau.
  • Clefts during phase III indicating spontaneous breathing efforts during controlled mechanical ventilation.
  • The cleft is caused by lack of synchronous action between the intercostal muscles and diaphragm - most commonly caused by inadequate muscle relaxant  and sedation causing patient to take spontaneous breaths.
  • As the muscle relaxant is given the curve become normal in shape and plateau is normal.


Reference: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1311.

choices.text: Grey body with black and white shoulder

The color of a medical oxygen cylinder is a black body, along with a white shoulder.

questions.text: Core temperature measurements usually are not taken from which site during general anesthesia?
questions.solution:
• The oesophagus is the most frequently used site in anaesthetic practise for temperature monitoring, despite the fact that pulmonary artery is the gold standard location for core temperature measurement.
  • The most accurate site to obtain core body temperature is the Hypothalamus. It is located in the base of the brain and acts as the body's thermostat.
  • Tympanic membrane can also be used to monitor core body temperature
  • Core temperature are usually not taken from Rectum due to its variation by external factors.


Reference: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 2342, 2343.

questions.text: Just before entering the epidural area during a lumbar puncture, a snap is felt. Which structure's piercing is responsible for this?
questions.solution:
Before reaching the subarachnoid area during a lumbar puncture, the needle travels through the following anatomical structures:
Skin; subcutaneous tissue; supraspinous ligament; interspinous ligament; Ligamentum flavum; Dura mater; Arachnoid mater

A distinct sense of "give away" is experienced when the ligamentum flavum is penetrated.


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 867.e1,867.e2

choices.text: General anesthesia with IV induction by ketamine
General anesthesia with IV induction by propofol followed by maintenance with fluranes

questions.text: A pregnant woman with placenta previa began to bleed as she went into labor. Her BP was 80/50 mm Hg. Due to severe shock, a lower-segment caesarean section was scheduled. What kind of anesthetic do you have in mind for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. General anesthesia with IV induction by ketamine
 
  • Current clinical scenario suggests patient in Shock with unstable vitals.
  • She needs to be delivered through C-section while receiving general anaesthesia.
  • Because GA is a more controlled modality and spinal anaesthesia has a significant risk of hypotension, GA is preferable.
  • Although neuraxial anesthesia is typically preferred, in certain emergent situations (e.g., fetal bradycardia, maternal hemorrhage or coagulopathy, uterine rupture, maternal trauma) general anesthesia is needed for cesarean delivery because of its rapid onset.
  • In addition, it allows for a controlled airway, controlled ventilation, and in some scenarios such as massive hemorrhage, improved hemodynamic control and perhaps decreased maternal psychological stress in comparison to neuraxial anesthesia.
  • In situations of acute shock, ketamine is the drug of choice.
  • Ketamine increases arterial blood pressure, heart rate, and cardiac output in a biphasic manner. Ketamine causes the systemic release of catecholamines, inhibition of the vagal nerve, inhibition of norepinephrine reuptake at peripheral nerves and non-neuronal tissues such as the myocardium, and norepinephrine release from sympathetic ganglia
  • Trauma patients with extensive blood loss (shock) are typical candidates for rapid-sequence anesthesia induction with ketamine.


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 664, 665, 1421, 2023.
Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 724.

questions.text: Which of these drugs is most frequently used prior to administration of  anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Amongst the given options, Glycopyrrolate is the drug used most frequently prior to anesthesia. 

 
Glycopyrrolate is an anticholinergic medication and is used to decrease stomach, mouth, and throat secretions prior to surgery.

  • Glycopyrrolate is a synthetic quaternary ammonium derivative of atropine. Due to its quaternary structure, which is charged in nature, it cannot cross the blood brain barrier and hence its anticholinergic effects are confined to the periphery. Hence, it is used more frequently compared to other anti-cholinergics. 
  • The activity of glycopyrrolate also lasts longer than that of atropine.
  • Often, anesthetic agents are combined with premedication of a barbiturate or benzodiazepine and an antisialagogue (e.g., glycopyrrolate) to facilitate management. The premedications reduce the dose requirement for anesthetic agent, and the antisialagogue reduces the sometimes troublesome salivation and respiratory secretions. This helps in prevention of aspiration.


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 666.

questions.text: A patient who was presented to the emergency room had the following chest X-ray taken. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Hydropneumothorax.

The given chest X-Ray shows presence of gas-fluid level in right hemothorax-suggestive of hydropneumothorax. 
The air fluid level is indicative of a hydropneumothorax diagnosis.
The presence of both air and fluid in the pleural region surrounding the lung is known as a hydropneumothorax.
Air fluid levels can be seen on an upright chest X-ray. Typically, the horizontal fluid level is clearly defined and runs the entire length of the hemithorax.

Other options: -

Emphysema- Narrow mediastinum, hyperlucent lungs and broadened costophrenic angle
Pneumothorax- Hyperlucency with collapsed lungs and trachea deviation to opposite side
Cardiac tamponade- Water bottle heart



Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 50, 123.
Weerakkody Y, Bickle I, Elfeky M, et al. Hydropneumothorax. Reference article, Radiopaedia.org (Accessed on 14 Sep 2024) https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-17362

questions.text:
A patient complained of lower back ache, which was improved by hot water baths and exercise. Below is a X-ray image.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Spyondylolisthesis.
 
  • The given lateral pelvic radiograph shows fracture of pars-interarticularis of L3 and L4 lumbar vertebra with anterior migration of body of L3 vertebral body over L4- suggestive of spondylolisthesis ( Beheaded scotty dog sign ).
  • The lower vertebra with the arrow on it has moved forward on the X-ray, suggesting spondylolisthesis. Spondylolisthesis, which most frequently happens after a fracture, is the forward displacement of a vertebra, particularly the fifth lumbar vertebra.
  • Spondylosis (a defect or fracture of the pars interarticularis of the vertebral arch) is the most common cause of spondylolisthesis, which should not be confused with a slipped disc, in which one of the spinal discs in between the vertebra has ruptured.
                          
Spondylosis is degenerative osteoarthritis of the joints between the center of the spinal vertebra or neural foramina. If this condition occurs in the zygoapophysial joints, it can be considered facet syndrome. If severe, it may cause pressure on nerve roots with subsequent sensory or motor disturbances, such as pain, paresthesia, and muscle weakness in the limbs.



Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 1262.
Gaillard F, Hacking C, Bell D, et al. Scottie dog sign (spine). Reference article, Radiopaedia.org (Accessed on 14 Sep 2024) https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-9954

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman arrives at a clinic with 2 weeks of decreased sleep, increased appetite, and hyperactivity. A manic episode diagnosis is made. Further investigation reveals four episodes of major depression in the previous two years. What medication will you give to this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Haloperidol

Treatment of acute mania:
  1. Utilize mood stabilizers (e.g- Lithium) and antipsychotics.
  2. Antipsychotics are tapered down when the acute episode is under control while mood stabilizers are kept up.
  3. Following the first episode, treatment lasts typically 6 to 9 months.
  • Due to its teratogenicity and high incidence of Ebstein's abnormality, lithium is contraindicated during pregnancy.
  • DOC for acute manic episodes in breastfeeding and pregnancy hence are Antipsychotics. 
  • The sole antipsychotic drug listed here is Haloperidol, which is the correct option.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 377-379.

questions.text: Which of the following does not belong to Beck's cognitive triad?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Guilt
 
  • According to Aaron Beck's theory from 1976, there are three different types of negative thoughts that are present in depression. His cognitive theory of depression includes the triad:
  1. Negative thoughts about the self - Worthlessness
  2. Negative thoughts about the world- Helplessness and
  3. Negative thoughts about the future - Hopelesness
  • The three components are interconnected and reinforce each other.
  • Guilt is a negative emotion that arises from a sense of responsibility for doing something wrong or causing harm to others.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 355.

questions.text: A young female patient on antidepressants arrives at the emergency department with hypotension and impaired sensory function. Wide QRS complexes and a right axis deviation are visible on the ECG. What is the best course of action for this patient's care now?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Sodium Bicarbonate.
 
  • The clinical features and ECG findings typically suggest a diagnosis of tricyclic antidepressant poisoning.
  • Treatment is primarily supportive with gastric lavage, respiratory assistance, fluid infusion, maintenance of BP and body temperature.
  • Acidosis must be corrected by sodium bicarbonate infusion given intravenously in doses of 100 mEq (1-2 mEq/kg), repeated every few minutes until BP recovers and QRS complexes start to narrow.
  • Diazepam may be injected I.V. to control convulsions and delirium.
  • Most important is the treatment of cardiac arrhythmias, for which propranolol/lidocaine may be used. 
Option 2 hemodialysis should not be used as TCAs have a significant volume of distribution and are largely protein-bound.
Option 3 Fomepezole is used as specific antidote of Methanol poisoning.
Option 4 Flumazenil is used as specific antidote of Benzodiazepine poisoning.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 487.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old boy with schizophrenia has been on risperidone for the past two months and is doing well. There is no history of the illness in his family.
How long should this patient's medicine be continued?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. 2 years
 
  • Numerous randomized trials have demonstrated that continuing antipsychotic therapy lowers the chance of recurrence for up to two years.
Most books mention treatment duration for schizophrenia as:
  • 1st episode: 1-2 years
  • 2nd episode: 2-5 years
  • 3rd/Recurrent: Lifetime
Though there is a controversy between 1 year and 2 years, 2 years is a safer answer than 1 year.



Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 319.

questions.text: Which of the following is not present in a child with a pervasive developmental disorder?
questions.solution:
• DSM-V recommends that intellectual disability should be ruled out before pervasive developmental abnormalities are identified.
  •  Pervasive developmental disorders (POD) is characterized by delays in the development of a variety of fundamental abilities, such as socializing and communication.
  • While some children with PDDs may have cognitive impairments, this is not a defining characteristic of the disorder. Instead, the hallmark features of PDDs are difficulties with social interaction and communication, as well as the presence of repetitive or stereotyped behaviors.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 1164, 1165.

questions.text: A mood stabilizer was controlling a male patient with bipolar disorder who had previously experienced 5 bouts of mania and 1 episode of depression in the previous 8 years. However, manic symptoms started to develop as he tapered off the medication. Which of the subsequent actions needs to be taken to increase drug compliance?
questions.solution:
• An evidence-based therapy intervention for patients/loved ones that offer knowledge to better understand and manage sickness is known as psychoeducation (a portmanteau of psychological education).
  • Psychoeducation is most frequently associated with serious mental illnesses like psychosis, clinical depression, anxiety disorders, etc.
  • Patients and family members who receive psychoeducation are taught problem-solving and communication techniques, and they are given information and tools in a compassionate setting. Results from many studies show that psychoeducation enhances rehabilitation, decreases relapse rates, and benefits families.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 1271, 1272.
